awd_titl_txt: Enhancing Research and Scholarly Training at the Desert Studies Center, California
awd_abstract_narration:
The Desert Studies Center (DSC) is a field station supported by the California State University system.  Through NSF-FSML support for strategic planning, the role of the DSC in desert research and scholarly training will be strengthened.  An important part of the plan will be to increase the DSC's influence on future generations of STEM scientists by increasing racial and ethnic diversity of the STEM workforce.  The plan will also emphasize cultivation of a broader set of research skills through cross-disciplinary research and training.

A number of inter-linked tasks will be used to achieve these goals.  A survey of, and visits to other FSMLs that face similar challenges as the DSC will be used to refine the current DSC Strategic Plan.  This Plan will guide development of an Operations Plan for improving infrastructure and logistical support of research at the DSC.  The final step will be to educate arid-land scientists about opportunities provided by the DSC, especially those of a cross-disciplinary nature, with an emphasis on recruiting use by faculty and students of minority-serving institutions.  These plans and a written summary of best-practices for increasing research and training at FSMLs operated by primarily-undergraduate institutions, as well as data associated with this program, will be made available through the DSC website (http://nsm.fullerton.edu/dsc/).

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this NSF-FSML planning grant was to strengthen the role that the Desert Studies Center (DSC) plays in desert research and scholarly training. The DSC is a field station operated by the California State University system.  As part of this goal, we also wish to help increase the racial and ethnic diversity of the STEM workforce and cultivate broader research skills through promotion of cross-disciplinary research and training.

The main objectives of the grant revolved around the development of a DSC Research Operations Strategic Plan. A draft of the plan, with recommendations, was completed for consideration by the Desert Studies Consortium Board of Governors, but many activities associated with development of the plan were also key outcomes of this project. 

In the process of developing the strategic plan, some of the longer-term objectives were realized indirectly.  For example, providing information about new research opportunities was part of the open house series, and these led to a number of new instructors using the DSC for both courses and starting new research. An affinity group in climatology was established to help modernize the DSC weather station, while another affinity group (astronomy) identified outreach activities, rather than research, as the best way to utilize the DSC. 

More than 60 students, many from racial and ethnic groups underrepresented in STEM disciplines, participated in the Desert Docents student program that contributed in many ways to the educational mission of the Consortium, including assisting with research. Two field courses, developed as part of the DSC strategic operations goals, provided course-based undergraduate research experiences (CURES) for over 70 students during the period of the grant, and these will continue into the future.

Although we did not deploy our FSML survey and thus could not publish the results (as guidance for developing field station research operations) the survey may still serve as a template for examining field station operations and student user diversity in the future. 

The ultimate objective, a draft Research Operations Plan, though not officially adopted, was completed and served as a de facto guide for a number of DSC decisions and activities, including the hiring of a permanent Research and Education Coordinator.  The other recommendations of the plan may help guide DSC research operations into the future, and towards strengthening the DSC's role in desert research and scholarly training.
